issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.description:
I do not necessarily think this is a bug but no other category seemed to fit correctly.

 

When I attempt to install the newest package on Ubuntu Bionic, the code seems to be converting my environmental variable {{ARROW_S3=ON}} to {{ARROW_S3=OFF}}.

!image-2020-10-22-08-10-10-757.png!

The issue seems to be with the {{libcurl4-openssl-dev}} package, but I already have this package installed.

!image-2020-10-22-08-10-19-711.png!

I am guessing that I am making a simple error, but curious if anyone else has come upon a similar issue with the install?

Thanks for the great package,
Mike
fields.summary: [R] Linux system requirements check needs to support older cmake versions

comments.body:
Thanks for switching venues to Jira. It helps us to keep all of our issues in one place.

The message you're seeing is coming from here: https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/r/tools/linuxlibs.R#L390

Which means that {{cmake}} can't find libcurl. Maybe it's a path issue?

Can you try:

{code}
cmake --find-package -DNAME=CURL -DCOMPILER_ID=GNU -DLANGUAGE=C -DMODE=EXIST
{code}

Thanks Neal - when I run that code, it does seem to find CURL. Does this need to return a value?

 

!image-2020-10-22-08-52-47-300.png!

Ok let's try this:

{code}
echo "find_package(CURL REQUIRED)" > CMakeLists.txt
cmake -DCMAKE_EXPORT_NO_PACKAGE_REGISTRY=ON -DCMAKE_FIND_PACKAGE_NO_PACKAGE_REGISTRY=ON .
$?
{code}

(then {{rm CMakeLists.txt}} to cleanup)
this is closer to what the R setup script is doing: https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/r/tools/linuxlibs.R#L400-L414

This is what I get when I run that code. 

!image-2020-10-22-09-09-34-977.png!

Hmm. Ok, can you clone apache/arrow, edit https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/r/tools/linuxlibs.R#L413 to switch the {{ignore.stdout}} and stderr arguments to FALSE so that it prints the cmake check, and then {{R CMD INSTALL arrow/r}}? Let's see if we get more insight into why it thinks you don't have libcurl.
I am guessing this is it: CMake Error: The source directory "" does not exist.

Is this the issue?

ensure_cmake <- function() {
 cmake <- (c(
 Sys.getenv("CMAKE"),
 Sys.which("cmake"),
 Sys.which("cmake3")
 ))

!image-2020-10-22-13-01-24-612.png!

Great, that's progress. Can you go right before that line and add {{print(cmake_cmd)}} and let's see if that tells us anything interesting.

Also, what is {{cmake --version}}, out of curiosity?
{{ensure_cmake}} calls {{find_cmake}} on that vector, which should result in a single path https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/r/tools/linuxlibs.R#L322

And here is the print(cmake_cmd) statement:

!image-2020-10-22-13-18-39-888.png!

Ok. The problem appears to be that cmake 3.10 doesn't support the -S argument: https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.10/manual/cmake.1.html

We'll need to change this command to work on older versions of cmake (arrow officially supports back to 3.2). 

A workaround for you today would be to download the latest cmake (https://cmake.org/download/) and, if you unzip/install it somewhere other than /usr/bin, set the path to cmake in the {{CMAKE}} environment variable.
